div.p: I. IV. symbols 35 symbols 36 symbols

Swam in the Potowmack alone, half an hour. Dr Huntt came and introduced Dr Caldwell, who also brought me a Letter from Dr Holley, the President of Transylvania University— Dr Caldwell invited me to attend his Lectures upon Phrenology, of which he is to give ten commencing this Evening at six O’Clock and delivering one Lecture every day till the course shall be completed— We were prevented from attending this day, by a long and heavy thunder Shower which came on just at the time with his lecture. Mr Brent came and introduced Count Vidua of a Son of the Prime Minister of the King of Sardinia, and Mr Vischer, Son of one of the principal Magistrates of Basle in Switzerland— The Count has been a very extensive traveller in the old world and is now a traveller of curiosity in this hemisphere— Appears to be a person of much intelligence and information. The intended employment of a public vessel for the protection of our Eastern Fisheries, induced Mr Southard to ask me for my controversial pamphlet on that subject published in 1822. I gave him a copy of it, and was this morning accidentally looking at another, which engaged my attention, and absorbed all the leisure of the day. The transactions connected with that Book were among the most important of my life, and the reperusal of it filled me with gratitude to Providence for having extricated me from one of the most desperate entanglements, in which the malice of man ever involved me— While rejoicing at the result of that struggle, let it serve me as an admonition, not to exult at the past, but to be armed in panoply for the future.
2. IV:30. symbols 1. symbols 2 symbols

Swam with John 3/4 of an hour against the tide, towards the bridge, but without reaching it— Mr Southard came to enquire, if I had heard further from Captain Porter— While he was with me two copies were brought in of a pamphlet, which Porter has had printed, addressed to me, containing a part of the Correspondence relating to the affair at Foxardo, the precept convening the Court of Inquiry—some of the proceedings before it; a defence of Porters transactions in that affair; and sundry documents most of which were rejected by the Court as not competent evidence— The reading of this pamphlet again occupied the day so that I wrote nothing. Porter complains of being oppressed, and labours to divert the attention of the Public from the censurable part of his conduct, by representing his invasion of Porto-Rico as if he had gone there in the fresh pursuit of Pirates. This Publication itself after notice that he would be tried by a Court-martial, is an appeal from the Government to the People. Mr Rhea of Tennessee called to visit me— Indulging perhaps a Rover’s disposition. He was more than twenty years a member of the House of Representatives with intervals once or twice when he lost his Election— He is a native of Ireland, and now at least four-score years of age— I asked him whether he would come again— He said he did not know— So that he will be a Candidate, if he sees any chance of succeeding. M’Corkle came for a subscription to a Bible of parallel texts— I told him that I would take a copy; but it has been a uniform practice of the President’s of the United States not to make subscriptions— Coll. Jones the Adjutant General brought me Lists of the Commissions issued from the War Department which I have signed— Appleton has come to receive final Instructions for his informal mission to Naples. Genl. Brown came on account of the absence of the Secretary of War, to enquire if there was any thing concerning which I wished to consult him— I asked him why the Board of Officers, which was convened in February to decide upon the Question of Rank between Generals’ Gaines and Scott, had declined giving any opinion upon the point immediately at issue between them. He said the Report of the board had been that they could give no useful decision in the case; which might be understood that they were so equally divided in opinion that their decision could not be useful, as advice to the Executive. I mentioned to him a Letter, I had received from Coll. William King; claiming to be appointed Coll. of one of the Regiments of Artillery, now vacant— He considers the question as resting between him and Coll. Bissell— Brown said that King was infinitely the better Officer of the two— King was tried in 1819. upon several charges, one of which was having given an order by which a Deserter, was put to Death without trial. He was found guilty of this charge, and sentenced to five years suspension. On the reduction of the army in 1821. he was left out of the new arrangement—and so was Bissell— In June 1820. King wrote two Letters to President Monroe, full of invective against the Court which had tried him; against Parker the then Adjutant General, against a Committee of the House of Representatives which had reported a Resolution requesting the President to strike King from the rolls of the army— These Letters he published six weeks afterwards prefaced with an Address to the People— He has now sent me a copy of this pamphlet, with a copy annexed of a third Letter to Mr Monroe, referring to the case of a Major Wyllys
who in 1786. put to death three Deserters without trial; against whom some measures were at first taken by the Old Congress, but whom after some months they directed to be discharged. With these enclosures King now writes me a Letter claiming this appointment to the vacant regiment, and extremely abusive upon Mr Monroe— His Letter is not positively disrespectful to me, but says he should have more confidence of succeeding with General Jackson or Mr. Crawford, both of whom had expressed opinions in his favour— I told Brown that as to the roughness of this address towards myself, it would have no influence in my mind against King; but his abuse of Mr Monroe was not all propitiatory to me; nor could I reconcile to my feelings of humanity the order to put to death a deserter without trial. Brown said the general sentiment of the army was not much against this— He had a decided aversion to Bissell, who he said was a gambler, and had enticed many young officers to the same vice, and utterly ruined them— I shall decide on this subject after full deliberation and consultation. Mr Shee brought me a Letter of introduction from John Sergeant— He came to enter a Caveat at the Patent Office, for some invention which he has in embryo, to turn Mill wheels, which he attempted to explain to me, and which he thinks very important— Mr H. Lee came to ask the return of a Letter from B. W. Leigh to him about titles of Honour in this Country, which he had some days since enclosed to me. He asked also for an original Letter from General Charles Lee, written in 1775 and an old document from a Committee of the Town of Boston in 1768. which he had sent me some weeks since, and now concluded to leave definitively with me.
3. V symbols 3. symbols 4 symbols

Bath with John. Cool and Cloudy— Swam fifty minutes against the tide upwards towards the Bridge, but without gaining ten yards— Major Van de Venter Chief Clerk of the War Department came, to enquire concerning the appointment of a Commissioner to mark the road from Missouri to Mexico, in the place of Pierre Menard who has resigned. I directed the appointment of Thomas Mather of Illinois— Mr Christmass is a young presbyterian Clergyman travelling to obtain subscriptions for building a Church of that denomination at Montreal in Canada. He has been there some time as a preacher; being a native of the United States, and educated at the Princeton Seminary. He said this Church was wanted for emigrants from the United States who are becoming numerous at Montreal; but who have to struggle there against great prejudices religious and political— I declined subscribing or contributing, thinking it not wise or patriotic to encourage emigrations from the United States to Canada. Mr Southard spoke of Captain Porter’s pamphlet, which he thought the weakest and most inefficient defence that he had ever read: resting upon an entire mis-statement of the case. I mentioned to him Letters from J. S. Cogdell naval Officer at Charleston S.C. asking for a leave of absence, conditional for recovery of his health— Mrs Adams went on a fishing party, and remained to dine with her brother— I heard this Evening part of Dr. Caldwell’s Lecture upon Phrenology— An abstract argument to prove that singleness of cause cannot in nature produce plurality of Effect—
4. IV:30. symbols 5. 10 symbols 6. symbols 1. symbols Stormy day.

A heavy gale of wind blew this morning. I nevertheless bathed and swam 45 minutes in the river, alone. A Storm of rain afterwards came on, and continued the whole day with little abatement of the gale. Mr Southard merely came to introduce Mr Scudder as a visitor— Mr Murray is an acquaintance of more than a quarter of a century; having first known him as a young traveller at Berlin. Van Rensselaer is the eldest Son of the member of Congress, the Patroon of Albany— J. J. Appleton, D. Brent, Murray, Van-Rensselaer, Count Vidua, and Mr Vischer dined with us— Vidua is a great traveller though a young man: well informed, and seeking information with great eagerness. Liberal in his principles, and discerning in his observations— Signed Commission to T. Mather. for marking the road from Missouri to Mexico, in the place of P. Menard. Also
5. V. symbols 7. symbols 8 symbols Storm continued.

Heard Little. Psalm 136.1. “O give thanks unto the Lord; for he is good: for his mercy endureth forever.” He gave notice that there would be this day no evening Service. Read Colman’s Sermon 13. upon Conscience. finished writing symbols

Heard Baker. Proverbs 29.1. [“]He that being often reproved hardeneth his neck, shall suddenly be destroyed, and that without remedy.” As frequently happens I could but contrast the temper of the two discourses, and in some respects that of the two preachers— Little sounds forth the goodness of God, and Baker holds out his terrors— Little infers from his text that God cannot very severely punish mortals, made frail by his own hands— Baker declares it an awful thing to fall into the hands of the living God— Yet there is more harshness in the personal character of Little, and more affectionate kindness in that of Baker.
I read Johnson’s Sermon 7. against Religious innovation. Its argument discloses the high Church Tory; and is remarkably weak— His text was very appropriate to his discourse.

div.p: 6. IV:15. symbols 9. symbols 10. symbols Sunrose 4.41.

Mr Brent came for directions respecting the Bills drawn by the Government of the Colombian Republic, to indemnify certain claimants Citizens of the United States— Some caution is necessary to secure the payments to the persons actually entitled to receive them. Mr Southard brought a draft of Instructions to Captain Parker, who is to proceed with one of our public vessels to the coast of our North-eastern frontier for the protection of the fishermen— I made some remarks suggesting certain alterations, to be made in the Instructions. He spoke of Captain Porter’s pamphlet, the publication of which he thought ought to be made the subject of a Charge, to be tried by the Court-Martial, to be convened on the Foxardo affair. The charge he thinks sustainable on two specifications—of gross insubordination in making an appeal
appeal to the public in print, upon the very case on which he had received notice that he was to be tried by a Court-martial—and in making false representations of it, by garbling the very documents that he produced— W. Brown came with reference to a complaint of a printer of the Laws in a newspaper at St. Francisville Louisiana— Mr Ironside was here on the same affair; but neither of them could explain how it happened that the printing of the Laws had been taken from him. Dr Waterhouse came in while Brown was with me, and being an old acquaintance of his mother and grand-mother, promised to visit them— The Doctor has just returned from his visits to Mr Jefferson and Mr Madison— Says Mr Jefferson is unwell; suffering with an incurable complaint; and apparently disspirited— Yet bearing up as well as he can— Mr Madison is well—and at his house, the Dr. saw Mr Monroe; who was then in Albemarle, for the sale of his Estate there. MessrsBulfinch and Persico, brought the design for the tympanum of the Capitol—America, between Justice and Hope, upon which various remarks were made— I sat about an hour to Mr Fürst for the die of his Medal— Dr. Waterhouse dined with us, and spent part of the Evening with me— Mrs Adams, Mary C. Hellen, Elizabeth C. Adams and my Son John attended at the Marriage of Baron Maltitz, Secretary to the Russian Legation, with Mary Lee, daughter to William Lee the second Auditor. symbols

John received a Letter from George, announcing the decease on the first of this Month of Mrs Abigail Welsh, wife of Dr Thomas Welsh—a first Cousin of my Mother; at whose house I resided four important years of my life, from 1790 to 1794. and with whom all my children have also resided several years at different periods of time— She was a woman of many good qualities, and whose memory I ought to hold in affectionate regard. I wrote the Doctor a short Letter

Signed Commission to Thomas L. Shaw, as Collector and Inspector of the Port of Georgetown, S.C. in the place of Moses Fort, dismissed— Order for discharge from prison and remission of fine of George Ritchie Boston Masstts.—
7. V:30. symbols 11. symbols 12. symbols

Mr Agg came in behalf of Mr Espada, commercial agent at Campeachy against whom there have been various complaints— Mr Espada gives Mr Agg the substance of his defence and hopes for a hearing. Mr Brent came for Mr Niederstetter to enquire when I would receive him; for which I appointed 1. O’Clock to-morrow— Mr Taylor of Alexandria came to introduce his Son— Mr Coolidge to repeat an application heretofore made by Letter for an appointment as a Clerk in any one of the Department, because he likes the residence of this District, and an office would suit his convenience— Dr Caldwell expressed a special wish that I would attend his Lecture this Evening which was to be peculiarly interesting— Mr Mercer introduced Mr Carter, as a member elect of the Legislature of Virginia. He is a young man, and was with my Son George at the University at Cambridge— Mr Adlum came to speak of Coll. J. E. Howard’s Testimony in the case of Captain Isaac Phillips. He had also some recollection of the subject himself; having resided at the time
time of Phillips’s dismission, in the same house with B. Stoddert, then Secretary of the Navy, and heard him then repeatedly speak upon the Subject— Mr Fürst finished the head upon the die of the medal he is executing for the Department of War—and is going for New-York to-morrow— He proposes striking a medal for his own benefit, besides those ordered for the Department— I attended Dr Caldwell’s Lecture, in which he entered upon the subject of craniology— He invited the non-attendance of the Ladies, at his Lecture of to-morrow Evening— The weather is sultry—Fahrenheit at 90. I took an hours walk after the Lecture alone; on returning home had, visits from Count Vidua, and Mr Vischer— Mr and Mrs Cutts and Dr Waterhouse— The Count is very inquisitive concerning the Literature, History and political Institutions of this Country— He is a fine performer on the Piano, and played for us two or three airs— He proceeds into Virginia with Mr Vischer to-morrow— Dr. Waterhouse also continues his journey homeward to-morrow— I have read two quires of paper which he has filled with an argument to prove that the first Earl of Chatham was the author of Junius’s Letters— I gave him some of my reasons for not subscribing to that creed; and some for holding Junius in lower estimation than he is generally held.
8. V. Bath— 50 minutes alone. Low tide— symbols 13. symbols 14. symbols

Mr Lindsley came to solicit subscriptions for a College at Nashville, Tennessee; which has recently instituted a La Fayette, and a Jackson Professorship, to be supported by contributions wherever they can be found— Dr Sewall came for Books for the Cony female Academy at Augusta, Maine, and will call again to-morrow— Commodore Tingey came to inform me that there was a frigate to be launched at the Navy-Yard, and to be named. She had indeed been called the Susquehannah, but without any authority, and might be named otherwise— He said she must be launched either next Monday at five in the afternoon; or not till towards the end of next week and at eight in the morning—of either of which he promised to give me suitable notice— Mr. J. J. Appleton intimated a desire to have a regular commission, for his mission to Naples; but I explained to him the reasons for which we had determined to take a different course—apparently to his satisfaction. Mr Niederstetter was presented to me by Mr Brent as Chargé d’Affaires from the King of Prussia; he was dressed in a full military Uniform, and made me a set Speech according to the Diplomatic usage of Ministers Plenipotentiary— It was longer than usual, but turned upon the ordinary topics; the friendly disposition of the King towards the United States; and his desire that the commercial Relations between the two Countries should as much as possible be promoted— He said he was directed to express the warm and grateful sentiments of his Government, at the kind feelings and sympathy which had been manifested here on the illness and decease of his predecessor Mr Greuhm; and he hoped I should be assured that he could faithfully execute the orders of his
of his Sovereign, only inasmuch, as he should follow the example of Mr Greuhm by discharging the duties of his trust in a manner which should secure the approbation and esteem of the Government of the United States— My answer was short and entirely unpremeditated— That I received him with great pleasure, as the representative of the Prussian Government— That the relations between the two Countries had always been interesting and uninterruptedly friendly— That they had also been distinguished by the negotiation at two different periods of Treaties, in which the first examples had been exhibited to the world of national stipulations founded upon the most liberal principles of maritime and commercial Law— Of the first of those Treaties, it was one of the glories, that it had received the sanction and ratification of the Great Frederic— It had been a part of the good fortune of my life, to have concluded with the Ministers of the present king the second Treaty; and I had during a residence of four years at the Court of the present king learnt to appretiate and to estimate his character, and that of his Nation, and to form attachments to them founded as well upon the personal kindness which I had invariably experienced from them, as upon the general impression produced by witnessing their merits— That in the friendly treatment which we had shewn to Mr Greuhm while he lived, and in the melancholy but feeling attentions at the time of his decease, we had born a most sincere testimonial to his excellent character and conduct, while paying that tribute of respect which was most justly due to his Sovereign— That the loss of him so immediately after his return to this Country, subsequent to a considerable term of absence, and when we had flattered ourselves with the hope of long enjoying his society, had been felt with deep concern— That I was well assured he, Mr Niederstetter would be governed by the same principles, which had attached us so warmly to his predecessor, and that I earnestly hoped he would have every motive to be satisfied with his residence in this Country. Genl. Brown conversed with me, concerning Letters from Genl. Scott, and from Colls.Leavenworth and Cummings, relative to the system of our intercourse and relations with the Indians. They were speculative and written some months since— I spoke also with Genl. Brown of a certain volunteer company of the District Militia, which voted to dissolve themselves, and then part of them attempted to form themselves into another company, and chose new Officers. Genl. Brown thinks this a very disorderly mode of proceeding which ought not to be sanctioned. There is also a certain question of rank between several of the Officers to be settled— After dinner I heard Dr Caldwell’s Lecture upon the organ of amativeness, which I thought more indelicate than philosophical— The weather was intensely warm, and I had no temptation to learn more either of phrenology or of Craniology— Dr Caldwell paid me some time after the Lecture an Evening visit— Mrs Frye, Mrs. W. S. Smith, Mr. T. B. Johnson and Mary Buchanan were likewise here this Evening— Mrs Adams was ill the latter part of the day, and confined in the Evening to her bed. The number of visitors, unrespited at this Season of the year, becomes oppressive and distracting, I have resumed the morning river bath at low tide.
9— III:30— Rose by mistake before day-light— Venus Morning Star.

list.item: Swam in the river one hour— Out from home 2 hours 30 minutes

div.p: Mr Smith brought a Letter from Mr Whittlesey M.H.R. from Ohio to Mr Clay; and was very solicitous for the Ashtabula Survey, for the laying out of the National Road. Mr Ironside came with the Proclamation and Papers relating to the Treaty with the Republic of Colombia. James Johnson mentioned that he was desirous of obtaining the appointment of Clerk of the Supreme Court of the United States, recently vacated by the decease of Elias B. Caldwell; or indeed any other place. Dr. Sewall called again for Books for the Cony female Academy at Augusta— I gave him a set of Otis’s Botta—a Copy of Allen’s Euclid; and Brackenridge’s Voyage to South-America. He brought with him a young man named Colby, from Massachusetts, but now a Student at the Columbia College at this place— Mr Custis brought and left with me a cane, cut, from a willow, at the grave of Washington, by Commodore Porter, some years since, and by him given to Genl. La Fayette— As he had another, he had on leaving this last Winter, left this in Custis’s keeping— Genl. La Fayette near Louisville in a Steamboat, struck upon a Snag Sawyer, or Planter on the river Ohio, and lost his baggage, including as Mr Custis supposes his cane— Custis therefore brought this to me, requesting me to forward it to Genl. La Fayette, by any opportunity that I should esteem to be safe. The Postmaster General brought me voluminous papers, relating to the appointment of a man named Scudder as Postmaster at Savannah, Georgia, in the place of Eleazar Early who has resigned and is a large defaulter— There are numerous and vehement remonstrances against the appointment of Scudder, and peremptory calls upon the Postmaster General to remove him and supply his place— General Macomb brought me the proceedings of a Court-Martial at West-Point, upon four or five Cadets who have been sentenced to be dismissed for having supped at a tavern. The General also brought and left with me the draft of an order partly approving and partly disapproving the proceedings of the Court—and remitting the punishment, with a sharp reprimand to the offenders— Warm day— Short Evening symbols
10. III:45. At dawn of day— Bath with John— Swam 1. hour 15 minutes— Out 2 hours 30.

list.item: symbols 17 Idolater’s to be stoned.— A King. 18. Levite’s portion. Wizzards and a prophet.

div.p:
Mr M’Guire is a respectable elderly man, who keeps a school, and came to solicit an appointment as a Justice of the Peace, or any other profitable employment. Mr Wirt left with me a written opinion as Attorney General, on a question made by the third Auditor upon the Construction of an Act of Congress allowing interest to the State of Virginia, upon certain expenditures during the late War for which the United States were chargeable. Mr Wirt’s
Mr Wirt’s opinion is favourable to the claim of the State, in its full extent; but being himself a citizen of the State, was desirous that I should give it a particular examination— I read attentively and approved it— Mr Southard brought a final draft of Instructions to Captain Parker, Commander of a Schooner to be stationed on the Coast of our Eastern fisheries; which I approved. I spoke to him of a Frigate, for the passage of Genl. La Fayette on his return to France— I proposed to name the Frigate about to be launched here the Brandywine, in compliment to him; and enquired if she could be equipped in Season for the time of his departure which he informed me he proposes about the 15th. August— The Commissioners of the Navy are to be consulted, whether the ship can be prepared in time— There are five Ships of the line, and five other frigates to be named; for the former of which we drew complicated lots, and from them selected the names of five States, Vermont, New-York, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and Alabama, to call them by— Upon the rivers we did not finally determine— I thought there was a great lack both of elegant taste and of lofty feeling in that Resolution of Congress which restricts the names of all our armed ships in future to States, rivers and Cities or Towns of this Union. The Shandean doctrine of names is more applicable to ships than to men; and although States Rivers and Towns, are good names to be given occasionally to ships, there are more affecting associations which might be awakened, and kept in perpetual remembrance by many others— Mr Samuel Plummer is a solicitant for a Clerkship or other Office, from Alexandria, but formerly of Newbury-Port, Massachusetts— Mr J. L. Skinner has claims yet unsettled against the Government, and at the Session of Congress before the last, there was a special Act in his favour, still to be executed— Dr Caldwell came to take leave. going upon his return to Kentucky to-morrow— Mr Southard called a second time with a draft of a Letter to Commodore Porter— He spoke also of the case of Scudder the Post-master at Savannah, and of that of Jacob Mull, the sailing Master, dismissed from the naval service by the Sentence of a Court Martial; and who solicits to be restored. Mr Southard favours his application. I thought he should obtain a recommendation from some Officers in good repute, which in his Letter he affirms all the officers on the station where he is would readily give. The family passed this Evening at Mr Frye’s— Johnson Hellen ill with a fever, and was bled.

Signed Land-grant Zanesville, Ohio 1. Cincinnati, Ohio 98— Reserves by Treaty of Saginaw of 24. Septr. 1819. To Petabonaqua or Phillis Beaufait 640. Acres 1 and to Nowokeshik or Francois Campau 640 Acres 1 =101

div.p: These visitors were of this day, and that which is mentioned of them as of yesterday should have been set down to this day— As also Mr Southard’s reference to his Letter to Captain Porter, and to the cases of Scudder and Jacob Mull— The family spent this Evening at Mrs W. S. Smith’s.
12. IV. Bath— Swam 1. hour 45 minutes out 2 hours 57 minutes.
symbols 21. Uncertain Murder. Children by 2 wives. Stubborn Son 22. Lascivious Crimes.
At St. John’s Church. Heard Mr Hawley from Proverbs 22.3. “A prudent man foreseeth the evil, and hideth himself: but the simple pass on, and are punished.”

Received the Memoir of Josiah Quincy junr. by his Son, the present Mayor of Boston—and read a great part of it. Found it well written— Modest and unaffected in the narrative, and supported by an interesting collection of Letters from persons distinguished in the History of our Revolution—
Read Colman Sermon 14. on Repentance and Conversion—or regeneration.
Heard Baker, from Psalm 19.7. “The Law of the Lord is perfect.”
Read Johnson Sermon 8—upon Self-conceit of wisdom— Fahrenheit at 90.

13. III:30. I attempted to cross the river with Antoine in a small canoe; with a view to swim across it to come back— He took a boat in which we had crossed it last Summer without accident— The boat was at the shore near Van Ness’s Poplars but in crossing the Tiber to the point, my Son John who was with us thought the boat dangerous, and instead of going with us went and undressed at the rock, to swim and meet us midway of the river as we should be returning— I thought the boat safe enough; or rather persisted carelessly in going without due attention to its condition— Gave my watch to my Son. Made a bundle of my coat and waistcoat, to take in the boat with me. Put off my shoes, and was paddled by Antoine, who had stripped himself entirely naked— Before we had got half across the river the boat had leaked itself half full, and then we found there was nothing on board to scoop up the water and throw it over. Just at that critical moment a fresh breeze from the Northwest blew down the river as from the nose of a bellows. In five minutes time it made a little tempest, and set the boat to dancing till the river came in at the sides. I jumped over-board, and Antoine did the same; and lost hold of the boat, which filled with water and drifted away— We were as near as possible to the middle of the river, and swam to the opposite shore. Antoine who was naked reached it with little difficulty— I had much more, and while struggling for life; and gasping for breath had ample leisure to reflect upon my own discretion— My principal difficulty was in the loose Sleeves of my shirt, which filled with water, and hung like two 56 lb weights upon my arms— I had also my hat, which I soon gave however to Antoine— After reaching the shore I took off my shirt and pantaloons—wrung them out, and gave them to Antoine to go and look out for our clothes, or for a person to send to the house for others, and for the carriage to come and fetch me— Soon after he had gone, my Son John joined me having swum wholly across the river expecting to meet us returning with the boat— Antoine crossed the bridge; sent a man to my house for the carriage, made some search for the drifted boat and bundles, and found his own hat with his shirt and bracers in it, and one of my shoes. He also brought over the bridge my Son’s Cloathes with my watch and umbrella, which I had left with him— While Antoine was gone, John and I were wading and swimming up and down on the other shore, or sitting naked basking on the bank, at the Margin of the river— John walked over the bridge
bridge home. The Carriage came and took me and Antoine home, half-dressed. I lost an old Summer coat, white waistcoat, two napkins, two white handkerchiefs, and one shoe. Antoine lost his watch, jacket, waistcoat, pantaloons and shoes— The boat was also lost— By the mercy of God our lives were spared; and no injury befell our persons. We reached home about a quarter before nine, having been out nearly five hours. I had been about three hours in the water, but suffered no inconvenience from it— This incident gave me a humiliating lesson, and solemn warning not to trifle with danger— The reasons upon which I justify to myself my daily swimming in the river did not apply to this adventure. It is neither necessary for my health, nor even for pleasure that I should swim across the river; and having once swum across it, I could not even want it as an experiment of practicability— Among my motives for swimming that of shewing what I can do, must be discarded as spurious, and I must strictly confine myself to the purposes of health, exercise, and salutary labour.

Brown— Genl. I sent for him. Conversed with him on the proceedings of a Court-martial upon a soldier named Allison, whom they sentenced to be shot for desertion twice— I told the Genl that I could not approve this sentence— Death was too severe a punishment for desertion in time of Peace— This was my own opinion, and I believed so decidedly that of the Nation, that an execution for this offence would greatly shock the public feeling. Genl. Brown said there was no example of a capital punishment for desertion in time of peace. He complained that there was no adequate punishment for this offence, and lamented the abolition of stripes— He said that he had laboured earnestly to raise the moral character of the army to which end he believed a most efficacious expedient would be a judicious and impartial system of promotion from the ranks to subaltern office, and an increase of the pay of non-commissioned officers— He said also he had directed to recruit the army only from native Citizens of the Union; the foreigners being always the most troublesome and vicious part of the army.
I directed a pardon, conditional to issue for Bryant Johnson.
Mary Buchanan came to pass some time with us.
Johnson Hellen convalescent symbols
14. IV:15. Saw the first beam of the Sun at 4:37
